ORAL ANSWERS TO QUESTIONS

CENTRAL PROVIDENT FUND
(Rate of contribution)


    1. Mr Ang Nam Piau asked the Minister for Labour whether Singapore needs such a high rate of Central Provident Fund contribution and if he will consider lowering the rate of contribution for wage earners when they reach the age of, say, 40 years and 50 years.

     The Minister for Labour (Mr Ong Pang Boon): Mr Speaker, Sir, whether the current rate of CPF contribution is adequate or excessive depends on the social security

Column: 1376

purposes CPF savings are made to serve. The primary purpose of CPF savings is to provide for members' old age. They are also an easy source of funding for the large number of members who use it to purchase flats and houses under the approved housing schemes. Further, in the future, there may be other social security needs, such as the two insurance schemes I mentioned in Parliament last week, to which CPF contributions will be put to use. If these social security needs are to be met, CPF contributions have to be maintained at current level.

    As to the lowering of the rate of contribution for those above 40 years of age, I would like to mention that their social security needs are the same as those of younger age. Many of them are still using a

Column: 1377

substantial portion of their CPF contributions to meet the monthly payments for their flats and houses. Further, CPF records show that at the end of 1979 the average balance of members in the age group between 40 and 45 years who used their CPF savings to purchase flats or houses was about $10,500. The corresponding figure for those between 50 and 55 years was $12,000. With life expectancy increasing to 65 years for males and 70 years for females, workers need to save more to tide over a longer period of retirement. Unless sufficient savings are accumulated by maintaining the current level of contributions for those above 40 years, workers' standard of living in retirement will be considerably lowered.

IN-CAMP TRAINING FOR RESERVISTS


    2. Mr Ang Nam Piau asked the Minister of Defence if he will consider shortening the period of annual in-camp training for reservists in order to minimize the inconvenience caused to them.

     The Minister of State of Defence (Mr Bernard Chen) (for the Minister of Defence): Mr Speaker, Sir, may I thank the hon. Member for addressing this question, as it gives me an opportunity to clarify a common misconception held by many members of the public.

    The main fighting arm of the Singapore Armed Forces is provided by the reserves. In war, the reservists, like their full-time counterparts, are required to fight at the front line. They are not called upon to fight only when the active force is spent. Although a person is called up to serve 2 to 2 1/2 years of full-time national service, this period only enables him to learn the basic skills of combat. To maintain these skills and to improve on them, a soldier still has to return to the SAF annually to do continuation training in the SAF Reserves. He will also have to keep up with the development of new doctrines and learn to operate new equipment which he may not have the opportunity to do while in active service.

Column: 1378



    Continuation training and upgrading of skills in the reserves are therefore necessary and they form an integral part of the comprehensive military training we are providing our citizens to defend their country if ever the need arises. Our reservists and their employers must not consider annual in-camp training as an inconvenience they have to put up with. Since we are unable to maintain a full-time standing army large enough to meet our defence requirements, the national service system which combines active and reserve service is still the best way of ensuring that we have the desired defence capability. National service, both active and reserve, must therefore be taken seriously by all concerned and the vital role which the SAF reservists play should be recognised.

    Under the Enlistment Act, 1970, citizens are obligated to serve up to the age of 40 (or 50 if he is an officer or a person with special skills) and for a maximum of 40 days of in-camp training a year. Presently, SAF reservists are called up for in-camp training for an average of two to three weeks annually. This is very much less than the period provided for by the law. Mindef is considering extending the period of annual in-camp training and the number of years of reserve training for reservists, especially officers, to enable them to acquire greater military skills. Upgrading our overall military preparedness can only be achieved if reservist officers serve a longer period in the reserves. The experience they accumulate over the years will be crucial in guiding and developing new reserve units.

    Over the years, Mindef has also improved the administration of in-camp training for reservists. Presently, reservists are given at least six weeks' notice to report for routine reporting. At the time when they report for routine reporting they are given another six weeks' notice of their impending in-camp training. The reservists therefore know that they will be doing in-camp training three months in advance from the time they receive the notice for routine reporting. To minimise the disruption to the reservists' civilian occupation, Mindef is considering doubling this period of notice, i.e. six months.

Column: 1379

As far as possible, Mindef will also not call them up for more then one in-camp training a year. The exception will be when such reservists are required for military exercises or for short periods to test their physical fitness. If a reservist is unable to attend in-camp training at the specified period, he may apply for deferment. He will then be recalled for make-up training at a later date. Inconvenience for the reservists, if at all existent, should in this way be minimised.

     Mr Ng Kah Ting (Punggol): Mr Speaker, Sir, as the responsibility for the defence of Singapore falls on the reservists, I would like to ask the Minister of State of Defence what steps are being taken to correct the misconception that national service ends after 2 to 2 1/2 years and that reservist training is just for training purposes?

     Mr Bernard Chen: Mr Speaker, Sir, Mindef is trying to tack!e this problem on two fronts. First, within the SAF itself, commanders have been told to inform those reservists under their charge that while in active service they are trainees and that such training will continue into the Reserves and even when they come back for reserve training the skills that they learn will complement what they have learnt in active service. In this way they become more efficient and more proficient than when they were in active service.

    On the second front, we would like, in the near future, to mount an education programme to inform the public, especially employers and parents, of the need for the reserve service to be part and parcel of the military service that their children or their employees are undergoing. Presently, the problem is not with the reservists themselves. After going through 2 to 2 1/2 years of training, I think they appreciate the need for further refurbishment of skills. The problem lies with the people who are not directly involved in military service but who stand to lose, for example, employers, because when the reservists are away, it means that they have to get someone to take their place.

Column: 1380

Otherwise there may be man-hours lost. We hope that through this education programme the employers will be convinced that defence needs are as important as the needs for a growing economy and that economic prosperity cannot be achieved without a credible defence. This will take some time because it involves sacrifice on the part of employers, but through regular exchange of information, especially with those who are involved, we hope to get this message across.

     Mr Ng Kah Ting: Sir, what about those people who are self-employed? Many a time I come across reservists who are self-employed and they complain that when they go for reservist training their business is affected. In such a case, what plans has the Ministry of Defence got to help them overcome disruption of their own business?

     Mr Bernard Chen: Mr Speaker, Sir, currently there is a scheme which enables us to grant make-up pay for both employees as well as the self-employed. Reservists who come in for training will be compensated by make-up pay. This scheme includes the self-employed category, such as doctors. By giving them ample notice, like six months in advance, many of them should be able to find replacements for whatever position they are holding. Surely, when they themselves want to go for holidays they will also have to find a replacement to take over their business unless it is assumed that most of them do not take even a single day's holiday, i.e. work 365 days a year.

    Among the professionals, reservist training should not pose 9 problem. There is a scheme where doctors can always get other doctors to take their place when they go away on holiday or on business. They can make the same arrangement when they go for in-camp training. The essence is that we should give sufficient notice to them so that they have ample time to get any replacement that they find necessary to do their job while they are away. In most cases, in-camp training does not last more than two weeks. So I do not think that their business will be seriously affected, either in income or at the prospect of losing their clients.

HAW PAR VILLA
(Preservation and maintenance)


    3. Mr Ang Nam Piau asked the Minister for Trade and Industry if the Government has any plan to preserve and maintain Haw Par Villa which attracts tourists and Singaporeans with its works of art depicting scenes from Chinese mythology.

     The Minister for Trade and Industry (Mr Goh Chok Tong): Mr Speaker, Sir, may I first of all explain that Haw Par Villa does not belong to the Government and, therefore, any plans to preserve and maintain the Villa must come from the owners.

    In April 1979, the owners, Haw Par Brothers (Pte) Ltd. made an offer to the Government to take over the Villa and the land, i.e. Haw Par Brothers (Pte) Ltd. was prepared to donate Haw Par Villa to the Government. The Singapore Tourist Promotion Board, on behalf of the Government, was agreeable, in principle, to take over the Villa as it is a major tourist attraction, provided that the land can be transferred free from encumbrances of any lease or sub-lease, if any. There is a lease between Haw Par Brothers (Pte) Ltd. and Haw Par Brothers International Ltd., whereby the land has been leased to Haw Par Brothers International Ltd. for 20 years from 1970. Haw Par Brothers International Ltd. was reluctant to surrender the lease, and thus the Government was unable to take over the Villa.

    Recently, however, Haw Par Brothers International Ltd. suggested to the Singapore Tourist Promotion Board to join with them in a venture to jointly preserve and maintain the attractions of Haw Par Villa. The proposal is under study by the STPB.

     Dr Lau Teik Soon (Serangoon Gardens): Mr Speaker, Sir, I beg to move,

    That the sum to be allocated for Head W be reduced by $10 in respect of Object Group 1100 of Subhead Code WA-01 of the Main Estimates.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, I would like the Hon. Minister to enlighten the House with regard to the Government policy concerning the provision of homes for the aged, taking into account the increasing number of old folks over the years. Presently, the Government has only the Woodlands Home and Woodstock Home for the Aged, while a good number of homes are being managed by charitable and civic organisations.

    With the increasing number of aged in the future, it is necessary for the Government to take on a greater role to provide more space for the aged who do not have anyone to depend on. The Government cannot expect the private sector, which is already carrying a heavy burden, to continue to provide a major share of the space that is needed. Many of the aged would have served the country in various capacities and the least the Government can do is to provide them with a roof over their heads.

    Of course, the Government should encourage more charitable and civic organisations to maintain and provide more space for the aged. In this connection, I would urge the Ministry to assist these organisations in the implementation of their plans to establish new homes. More than that, I hope the Hon. Minister will consider providing a grant to charitable and civic organisations to encourage them further to establish such homes.

    Besides the mere provision of space for the aged, the Government should consider providing certain basic amenities in these homes, including recreational facilities, vocational work and hobby-crafts. Then the residents can occupy their time with some work and leisure. The Government should give incentives for the charitable and civic organisations to provide such recreational

Column: 1383

and vocational facilities. Such incentives can be by way of grants or material assistance.

    I would like to seek the Hon. Minister's comments on the points I have made.

     Haji Sha'ari bin Tadin (Bedok): Mr Speaker, Sir, according to statistics released at a recent seminar on The Aging and the Aged, Singapore will have over 192,000 people aged 60 years and over by 1985. This number will increase to about 233,000 by 1990. At present we have an estimated 169,000 people who are over 60 years old. Already, problems associated with old age are surfacing at a regular rate and organisations like the Singapore Action Group of Elders (SAGE), the Housing and Development Board and the People's Association which recently announced schemes for retirees, are doing their part to help solve some of these problems. Organisations like SAGE, which cater for the needs of our senior citizens, are at most stop-gap measures but it will be sagacious for the aged to be looked after by the family in the long run. I am not advocating the concept that the Government should wash its hands of the business and leave the senior citizens to their own plight, for the Government has still an effective role to play in caring for them. It has been estimated that by 1985 we would have a population of some 192,000 who would be above 60 years of age. Apart from it being a financial burden on the Government, there will not even be enough land to build all the needed homes to house these unfortunate people. What is urgently required at present is the promotion of the concept that the care of the aged must rest more and more on the family unit in our society. If this concept can be successfully promoted, then we shall arrive at a stage when the aged will not be discarded by the younger set just because they have outlived their usefulness.

    Sir, we may need Western technology, but we must fight against the total Westernisation of our minds and our responsibilities. For one thing, our moral and traditional

Column: 1384

values are not exactly the same as those of the Westerners. In the West there is a built-in response to the problem of old age. The parents take care of themselves. Here, being Asians, we have not arrived at that stage. Yet I personally feel that we should not follow them, if by doing so we have to sacrifice part of our traditional values of preserving the family unit.

    I would like to propose that a campaign be mounted in the schools and other institutions to promote the concept of care and concern for one's elders among the young. A trust fund should also be set up by working members of the family for the non-working aged in their care. This could be a token contribution. It can be made compulsory, and the check-off system can be employed to siphon off a small percentage of their earnings towards this fund.

    As I have said earlier, Sir, going by the projected figures which I have just quoted, we can expect bigger and more acute problems looming in the years ahead. In view of this, I feel that the Ministry of Social Affairs should take the lead in tackling these problems. At present the Ministry does not have a unit or division that deals with problems relating to the aging or the aged. I would like to suggest, therefore, that a Gerontology Unit be established by the Ministry to look into all aspects and problems of the aged and to make a research into the problems of old folks, One of its terms of reference should be to guide and coordinate the efforts of both Government and private organisations to ensure that there is the least duplication and maximum impact.

    Sir, these measures should be implemented at the earliest possible moment. The society we produce will be a lonely one indeed if we do not seek to fathom and understand what loneliness is. In helping to ease the problem of loneliness of the aged we are, in effect, helping ourselves,

     The Acting Minister for Social Affairs (Dr Ahmad Mattar): Sir, let me first reply to the hon. Member for Serangoon Gardens. My Ministry's thinking on the care of the aged is

Column: 1385

that, as far as possible, they should be looked after by their own children. Children who have the means to look after their own aged parents should be encouraged to do so, so that only the aged destitutes or those who for financial reasons cannot live with their children can be allowed to be accommodated in the homes for the aged.

    Sir, based on the number of requests received by my Ministry, there seems to be a trend these days for the old folks to be abandoned by their children. Hon. Members in this House will agree with me that this practice would have been unthinkable among the older generation. We must, therefore, shame the younger generation, particularly those who have the means, into abandoning their aged parents in old folks' homes. We must fight this trend. We must reinforce our Confucianist, Islamic, Hindu or Christian ethics and encourage the extended family system unless, as I have stated earlier, financial circumstances are such that the children just cannot look after their aged parents.

    As for the building of more homes for the aged, my Ministry plans to build one more home for the aged. At this point of time, the plan is still in its embryonic stage. In the meantime, the Government will continue to encourage community groups to set up homes for the aged within housing estates. This is in line with my Ministry's policy, naM31y, the aged should be encouraged to live within the community instead of living in some remote institutions.

    In the last two years, the Social Welfare Department has managed to promote the setting up of 11 community homes for the aged in Housing Board estates. The Department is also encouraging voluntary welfare groups to set up homes to cater for the chronic sick.

    The hon. Member for Serangoon Gardens also wants to know the kind of assistance the Government can give towards the establishment of homes for the aged which are not sited in HDB estates. Sir, the nature of Government's assistance depends on the nature of the problem. Let me quote two

Column: 1386

examples, First, the Sree Narayana Mission wanted to start a Home for the Aged Sick. The Social Welfare Department helped the Mission in leasing the reverted properties at Blocks 87 and 89, Canberra Road, from the Commissioner of Lands to establish the Sree Narayana Mission Home for the Aged Sick.

    In another instance, when the Home for the Aged Sick in Payoh Lai, off Upper Serangoon Road, was affected by a major development scheme, the Social Welfare Department successfully made representations to the Ministry of National Development for the Home to remain at the site and to be integrated with the redevelopment programme. Yet another example, Sir, is the Ling Kwang Home for the Aged which, I believe, is to be set up in Ang Mo Kio by the Bible Presbyterian Welfare Services, In this case my Ministry sought the assistance of the HDB to undertake the clearance of squatters at the site for the proposed Home.

    The Social Welfare Department will also recommend that homes for the aged be granted the status of "an institution of public character", if such homes are run on a charitable basis and conform with the guidelines of the Department on the minimum standards of care. Financial assistance to the homes run by voluntary organisations will continue to be given by way of Public Assistance allowance to residents of such homes. As at February this year, a total of 530 residents in these voluntary homes received the allowances at current rates.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, I fully agree with the hon. Member that homes for the aged should not just look after the physical needs of the residents. They should also provide social, recreational and other activities to enable the residents to lead a normal life. This is exactly the position in our Homes for the Aged today, where both indoor and outdoor recreational programmes are provided. Indoor activities include the making of handicrafts, reading, watching television, listening to radio, playing chess and so on. We even allow mahjongg to be played.

Column: 1387



     Dr Augustine H.H. Tan (Whampoa): Encouraging gambling!

     Dr Ahmad Mattar: Gambling is strictly prohibited. Organised tours to places of interest in Singapore and occasional viewing of film shows at cinemas are examples of the outdoor activities organised for the aged. Talking of film shows, Sir, the hon. Member may be pleased to know that the Social Welfare Department has just received a donation of $6,000 for the purchase of equipment to screen film shows at the four Social Welfare Homes under the Department.

    There are also ample opportunities for social interaction, as residents are allowed to receive visitors and to visit friends. Residents who are physically fit are encouraged to do simple chores, like gardening, under supervision. However, Sir, there are also old folks who wish to be left alone, For such residents who do not wish to participate in the activities organised, their wishes are well respected.

    Sir, let me now come to the suggestion of the hon. Member for Bedok. If I understand correctly, the word "gerontology" refers to the scientific study of old age and its diseases. The Member should have made the suggestion to the Minister for Health for his consideration. However, as the Member has also mentioned the recreational needs of old people and how to keep them occupied, I shall attempt to answer him from my Ministry's point of view.

    It is not correct for him to say that my Ministry does not have a unit which looks after the aged. The Social Welfare Department already has, what it calls, the Aged Services Unit. The priority of this Unit is to look after the destitute aged and to provide for their needs. The Unit has been encouraging community and voluntary organisations to set up community homes for the aged and the chronic sick. It maintains close liaison with other civic bodies which provide recreational and social activities for the aged. The Singapore Council of Social Service, which is a statutory body under the Ministry of Social Affairs, has a committee

Column: 1388

for the care of the aged. Studies have been conducted on the problems and needs of the aged and the resources available. The Council is also planning to have a Day-Care Centre for the Elderly. It is also looking into such matters as obtaining cinema concession rates for the aged.

    The People's Association and the Citizens' Consultative Committees have various activities and projects to look after the aged. A good example is the Bukit Merah Old Folks' Club which, I believe, is run by young volunteers in coordination with the Welfare Sub-Committee of the Bukit Merah CCC. Then there is, of course, the Singapore Action Group of Elders (SAGE) which is under the active guidance of my Senior Parliamentary Secretary.

    Close liaison is maintained between my Ministry and these various organisations which provide recreational and social services for the aged. Sir, at this point of time, I feel there is no need for my Ministry to duplicate the good services of the voluntary sector. Hence, there is no need for my Ministry to set up a gerontology unit as suggested by the Member for Bedok.

     Dr Augustine Tan: Mr Speaker, Sir, I was a bit puzzled over two points mentioned by the Hon. Minister for Social Affairs. First, he said he was against gambling and yet he advocated mahjongg. I may be wrong, but I always associate mahjongg with gambling. Secondly, he stated that there is a trend for the old to be abandoned in Singapore and yet I heard him distinctly say that he is trying to shame the young into abandoning the old. He should look at his text again or maybe look at the Hansard. A slip of the tongue perhaps, but indicative of what goes on in the mind!

    Sir, I do agree with the Government's philosophy that we should encourage our young people to have filial piety. But how exactly is the Ministry of Social Affairs going about this process of educating our young people? People in Singapore seem to respond more to a combination of the carrot and the stick. Perhaps the Minister can tell us something about the policies that Government is planning in this respect. Are we, for

Column: 1389

example, giving more reliefs for the support of aged parents? Right now, it is $750 per year and I hope the Hon. Minister for Trade and Industry is listening, in case he is preparing next year's Budget.

    Sir, the other point which I wish to raise is in connection with the promotion of community homes by the Ministry of Social Affairs in conjunction with voluntary bodies. I am familiar with such homes because a new one has been set up by the Methodist Church in Whampoa recently. But these homes are set up for the aged people who are still able and capable of caring for themselves physically, who are not chronically sick, not invalid nor need 8ttention by the bedside. Is his Ministry looking into the needs of such people, as there must be an increasing number of old people who need physical attention? I think the most dreaded thing about old age is not simply growing old but being unable to look after one's own bodily functions. Is there provision anywhere to help these people?

    The Minister talks about building one more Home for the Aged and he seems to be happy that it is taking quite some time to be built. Will he tell us something more about the accommodation of this new home that is being planned? How many places are available? Will this new home cater for the category of old people which I have mentioned, namely, those people who are not able to look after themselves physically?

    A further point which I wish to raise, Sir, is with regard to the social welfare allowances for the aged. Recently, the Government added another $20 per person. I think it was from $40 to $60. I would like the Hon. Minister to tell this House how his Ministry went about determining that $60 would be a sufficient minimum to keep body and soul together, whether for an aged person or for a destitute younger person. Will he enlighten this House?

     Dr Ahmad Mattar: Mr Speaker, Sir, on the question of Social Welfare assistance, since the hon. Member for Kolam Ayer will be raising this matter under the appropriate

Column: 1390

Subhead, I would rather not answer the question now.

    The hon. Member for Whampoa wants to know the details of the new Home for the Aged to be set up by the Social Welfare Department. As I mentioned earlier on, Sir, it is still in the embryonic stage, and I hope the Member knows what "embryonic stage" means.

    The other point which the Member raised is about mahjongg being a form of gambling. It all depends on what one thinks of the game. If the Member wants to think of it as a form of gambling, then it is a form of gambling. So it depends on what goes on in the mind. Football is a good example. People go to the National Stadium either to watch football for the fun of it or to gamble on it. It all depends on what goes on in that little mind.

    I am not quite sure, Sir, of the question which the Member raised on the physical needs of the aged. Perhaps the Member could repeat it. I was busy thinking of a suitable reply to his question on mahjongg. I might have missed the point,

     Dr Augustine Tan: Sir, I certainly hope the Hon. Minister would never get to the stage where he cannot control his bodily functions!

     Dr Ahmad Mattar: Sir, I still have not got the question.

     Dr Augustine Tan: Mr Speaker, Sir, if I were to be explicit about those functions, you will rule me out of order. I am talking about the physical needs of old people who are unable to go to the toilet by themselves. They are unable to bathe themselves. Is that clear enough, Mr Minister?

     Dr Ahmad Mattar: Sir, each home for the aged, whether it is being run by the Government, i.e. the Social Welfare Department, or whether it is being run by voluntary organisations, has a pool of voluntary nurses who help to look after the so-called physical needs of the aged particularly those who are non-ambulant. Minister really to visit those people who are sick to the point where they need to be cleaned up every two hours in the middle of the night. How does he expect these voluntary nurses and workers to look after these old people in this way? Is he aware of these realities? He is a young man. He does not know what is life.
